docs.title: Concept: Understanding High Availability and Failover with Load Balancers
Overview
docs.text:
High Availability (HA) ensures that systems remain accessible even when individual components fail. Load balancers are a key part of HA strategies, distributing traffic across multiple servers and handling failover.

Audience: IT professionals, support engineers, developers Skill Level: Beginner–Intermediate

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
• High Availability (HA): Designing systems to minimize downtime.
  • Failover: Automatic redirection of traffic when a server becomes unavailable.
  • Load Balancer: A device or software that distributes traffic among servers.

docs.title: How Failover Works
docs.text:
1. Health checks detect an unhealthy server
  2. Load balancer removes the server from rotation
  3. Traffic is routed to healthy servers
  4. Failed server is restored and re-added

docs.title: Example Diagram
docs.text: • Insert a simple diagram later showing clients → load balancer → servers

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use multiple load balancer nodes (active-passive or active-active).
  • Monitor system health regularly.
  • Test failover scenarios before production use.

docs.title: Restoring SQL Database in Azure Portal
Introduction
docs.text: This guide describes how to restore a SQL Database using the Azure Portal. It covers selecting the correct subscription and database, performing a restore, configuring the database, and optionally moving the restored database into an elastic pool.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Access to the Azure Portal with permissions to restore databases.
  • Knowledge of the production database name (for example xyz_prod).

docs.title: Restore procedure
docs.text:
1. Sign in to the Azure Portal

  2. Open: https://portal.azure.com/#home

  3. Open SQL Databases

  4. From Home, select SQL Databases.

  5. Change subscription

  6. If needed, switch the subscription to XYZ Production.

  7. Locate the production database

  8. Search for the company name (for example: XYZ) and open the production database (for example: xyz_prod).

  9. Start a restore

  10. Click Restore on the database blade.

  11. Set restore point and time adjustments

  12. Choose the backup/restore point you need.

  13. If the restore time crosses a daylight savings boundary:

    • For fall (clocks back): set the UTC offset to +6 hours (based on Central Time).
    • For spring (clocks forward): set the UTC offset to +5 hours (based on Central Time).

  14. Name the restored database

  15. Remove any timestamp from the suggested name and add a identifying suffix (for example: _andrew or _dr).

  16. Configure compute and storage

  17. Service tier: Standard
  18. DTUs: 400

  19. Backup storage redundancy: Locally-redundant backup storage

  20. Review and create

  21. Click Review + Create, verify settings, then Create.

  22. Wait until deployment completes.

  23. Open the restored resource

    • Click Go to resource once deployment finishes.

  24. (Optional) Copy or rename for data restore workflows

    • From the restored database Overview, use Copy if you need a separate copy.
    • Append dr (or another suffix) to indicate a data-restore copy.

  25. Select restore server

    • Example target server: restoresql01 (East US 2).
    • Confirm backup storage redundancy is set to Locally-redundant.

  26. Move the database into an elastic pool (optional)

    • Open the server (for example: restoresql01.database.windows.net).
    • Under SQL elastic pool, select restoresql01_ep01 → Configure → Databases → Add databases.
    • Check the newly restored database and click Apply, then Save.

  27. Clean up / delete old or test databases (if required)

    • From SQL Databases, select the database to delete.
    • Follow the delete confirmation steps:
    • Type your name when prompted.
    • Check the database (for example: xyz_prod_andrew) and click Delete.
    • Type delete to confirm.

These steps provide a comprehensive guide to restoring a SQL database in the Azure Portal, ensuring proper configurations and necessary adjustments are made throughout the process.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Guide: Converting Epoch Timestamps in SQL Server
Overview
docs.text:
When working with applications or logs that store timestamps in Unix epoch format, you may need to convert them into a human-readable datetime in SQL Server. This guide explains common issues, provides working solutions, and highlights pitfalls to avoid.

Audience: Database administrators, support engineers, and developers. Skill Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Problem
docs.text:
You have a column storing epoch timestamps (e.g., 1694467200) but queries return unreadable numbers instead of dates.

Example:

SELECT EventTimeEpoch FROM Logs;
-- Output: 1694467200

docs.title: Root Cause
docs.text: SQL Server does not natively store or interpret Unix epoch timestamps. Conversion requires explicit handling.

docs.title: Convert Epoch to DateTime
docs.text: SELECT DATEADD(SECOND, EventTimeEpoch, '1970-01-01') AS EventTime FROM Logs;

docs.title: Handling Milliseconds Epoch
docs.text:
If your data stores epoch in milliseconds:

 SELECT DATEADD(SECOND, EventTimeEpoch / 1000, '1970-01-01') AS EventTime FROM Logs;

docs.title: Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
• Forgetting to divide milliseconds by 1000 | results in incorrect dates.
  • Not accounting for UTC vs local timezone differences.
  • Using DATETIME instaed of DATETIME2 | potential precision issues.

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
Run this query to confirm conversion works:

SELECT TOP 5
  EventTimeEpoch,
  DATEADD(SECOND, EventTimeEpoch, '1970-01-01') AS ConvertedTime
FROM Logs;

Expected output should match known event timestamps.

docs.title: Tutorial: Automating F5 Load Balancer Tasks with PowerShell
Overview
docs.text:
This tutorial walks through automating a common F5 load balancer task — forcing a server offline — using PowerShell and SSH. It demonstrates scripting basics, automation workflow, and verification steps.

Audience: System administrators, support engineers Skill Level: Intermediate

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• PowerShell 5.1 or later
  • SSH access to the F5 load balancer
  • Appropriate permissions to manage pool members

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Connect to the F5 via SSH
  2. Run the PowerShell script to force a server offline
  3. Verify the server status
  4. Bring the server back online (if needed)

docs.title: Example Script
docs.text:
```powershell $server = "10.0.0.5" $pool = "web_pool"

ssh admin@f5 "tmsh modify ltm pool $pool members modify { $server:80 { session user-disabled } }"
